citeinfo.title: Changes in Anthropogenic Influences on Streams and Rivers: Imperviousness

descript.abstract: This dataset consists of three tables of data representing percent imperviousness from two sources, one source represents the period 2001-2011 (based on National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD)) and one source represents the period 1974-2012 (from the NAWQA Wall-to-Wall Anthropogenic Landuse Trends (NWALT) dataset). One table contains data for Hydrologic Unit Code 10 (HUC-10) areas, one for U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Level IV ecoregions, and one for 2010 U.S. county boundaries. Each table provides data from each of the two data sources.
descript.purpose: These data are intended to provide a framework in which watershed-specific studies of water quality in streams and rivers may be analyzed. The focus of the data is on anthropogenic changes over time.
descript.supplinf:
Three comma-separated text files are given here. Each file contains a "uniqid" field, which is the link to the data in other datasets in this product. The file representing HUC-10 areas has 15,458 rows, the file representing Level IV ecoregions has 967 rows, and the file representing U.S. counties has 3,109 rows. Imperviousness from the NLCD is derived primarily from remote sensing sources (see Xian and others, 2011), while imperviousness from the NWALT dataset is derived from land use class-based coefficients (Falcone, 2017). The NLCD imperviousness is likely to be more accurate, but is limited to the years 2001-2011, while NWALT-derived values span 1974-2012. The data sources provide generally very similar values for the areas measured in this dataset (for example, the r2 between the NLCD 2011 and NWALT 2012 values for HUC-10 areas is 0.98, and 97% of them are within 1% watershed imperviousness of each other), however they are not directly comparable. That is, users should use either the NLCD values as a time series, or the NWALT-derived values as a time series, but not mix them. See supportive documentation in references for more information on source data. All NLCD data are derived from the NLCD 2011 "October 2014 harmonized versions" of the NLCD 2001, 2006, 2011 (mrlc.gov). The stated USGS preferred citations for NLCD products are: NLCD 2001 products: Homer and others, 2007. NLCD 2006 products: Fry and others, 2011 NLCD 2011 products: Homer and others, 2015. NLCD 2011 Percent Developed Imperviousness: Xian and others, 2011. Citations for the boundaries used are: HUC-10 boundaries: National Resources Conservation Service, 2017; Level IV ecoregion boundaries: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 2013; 2010 counties: National Historical Geographic Information System, 2013. References: Falcone, J.A., 2017, Coefficient-based consistent mapping of imperviousness in the conterminous U.S. at 60-m resolution for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012: U.S. Geological Survey data release, https://doi.org/10.5066/F72F7KMG. Fry, J., Xian, G., Jin, S., Dewitz, J., Homer, C., Yang, L., Barnes, C., Herold, N., and Wickham, J., 2011, Completion of the 2006 National Land Cover Database for the Conterminous United States, Photogrammetric Engineering and Remote Sensing, Vol. 77(9):858-864. Homer, C., Dewitz, J., Fry, J., Coan, M., Hossain, N., Larson, C., Herold, N., McKerrow, A., VanDriel, J.N., and Wickham, J., 2007, Completion of the 2001 National Land Cover Database for the Conterminous United States, Photogrammetric Engineering and Remote Sensing, Vol. 73, No. 4, pp 337-341.
Homer, C.G., Dewitz, J.A., Yang, L., Jin, S., Danielson, P., Xian, G., Coulston, J., Herold, N.D., Wickham, J.D., and Megown, K., 2015, Completion of the 2011 National Land Cover Database for the conterminous United States-Representing a decade of land cover change information. Photogrammetric Engineering and Remote Sensing, v. 81, no. 5, p. 345-354. National Historical Geographic Information System, 2013, U.S. geographic summary data and boundary files, 2010: National Historical Geographic Information System, Integrated Public Use Microdata Series (IPUMS), county boundaries, accessed February 1, 2013 at: https://www.nhgis.org/. National Resources Conservation Service, 2017, Watershed boundary dataset (WBD): National Resources Conservation Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture, available at https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/main/national/technical/nra/geo/, accessed January 9, 2018 from https://nrcs.app.box.com/v/huc/folder/39640323180. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 2013, Level IV ecoregions of the conterminous United States: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development â€“ National Health and Environmental Effects Research Laboratory, accessed November 17, 2017 at: https://www.epa.gov/eco-research/level-iii-and-iv-ecoregions-continental-united-states. Xian, G., Homer, C., Dewitz, J., Fry, J., Hossain, N., and Wickham, J., 2011, The change of impervious surface area between 2001 and 2006 in the conterminous United States., Photogrammetric Engineering and Remote Sensing, Vol. 77(8): 758-762.

citeinfo.title: Coefficient-based consistent mapping of imperviousness in the conterminous U.S. at 60-m resolution for 1974, 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012

srcinfo.srccontr: NWALT-derived dataset from which imperviousness 1974-2012 were derived

procstep.procdesc: (1) Source data from the NLCD were downloaded (https://www.mrlc.gov/) and converted to grid format in March 2015. The source data for the NLCD are the October 2014 normalized version of data, where all years have been adjusted to agree with one another.
(2) Source data of imperviousness grids derived from NWALT were based on Falcone (2017a).
(5) HUC-10, Eco-IV, and county mean imperviousness were calculated using the zonalmean() command in ArcGIS Grid.

enttyp.enttypd: Data consist of comma-separated text files. There are three tables: imperviousness-county.txt, imperviousness-eco4.txt, imperviousness-huc10.txt
enttyp.enttypds: Surface Water Trends project, USGS National Water Quality Program

attrdomv.udom: Unique identifier for either "huc10"s, "county"s, or "eco4"s, where YYYY represents one of those three terms
